item.title: US Stocks Rise as Bond Selloff Eases, Business Activity Positive
item.description: US equities managed to halt a slide on Thursday as the Treasury selloff that hurt stocks eased and fresh economic data helped lift spirits on Wall Street.
item.dc:creator: Joel Leon

media:content.media:description: Traders work on the floor of the New York Stock Exchange (NYSE) in New York, US, on Wednesday, April 9, 2025. US equity futures extended declines on Wednesday with the S&P 500 Index trading on the brink of a bear market as China retaliated against the US and further raised tariffs on American goods.

item.title: Ryan Reynolds’ MNTN Shares Rise 60% After $187 Million IPO
item.description: Connected TV advertising platform MNTN Inc.’s shares climbed more than 60% after the company and some of its shareholders raised $187 million in an initial public offering.
item.dc:creator: Carmen Reinicke, Anthony Hughes

media:content.media:description: Ryan Reynolds

item.title: Ghana Sees $12 Billion a Year From Small-Scale Gold Mining
item.description: Ghana expects to rake in $12 billion a year from small-scale gold production if output doubles as planned.
item.dc:creator: Ekow Dontoh

item.title: TD Tumbles in Canadian Bond Rankings After Key Bankers Leave
item.description: In just a few months, Toronto-Dominion Bank’s ranking among Canadian bond underwriters has dropped to close to the bottom among its peers, after an exodus of fixed-income professionals.
item.dc:creator: Chunzi Xu

media:content.media:description: The Toronto-Dominion bank headquarters in Toronto.

item.title: Wall Street Halts Rout, But Fiscal Worry Lingers: Markets Wrap
item.description: Wall Street made a cautious comeback just a day after a Treasury selloff that shook markets around the globe, with stocks halting a slide amid a rebound in bonds. The dollar also advanced.
item.dc:creator: Rita Nazareth

item.title: UK to Pay Mauritius £101 Million a Year to Use Military Base
item.description: The UK agreed to cede an Indian Ocean archipelago to Mauritius while retaining control of a strategic military base on one of the islands, ending a long-running negotiation that had become a point of controversy for British premier Keir Starmer.
item.dc:creator: Kamlesh Bhuckory, Joe Mayes

media:content.media:description: Diego Garcia

item.title: Long-Term Bond Yields Soar Globally on Fiscal Policy Fears
item.description: From the US to Japan, long-term borrowing costs for the world’s biggest economies are surging as investors question the ability of governments to cover massive budget deficits.
item.dc:creator: Alice Gledhill, Mia Glass

media:content.media:description: The US Capitol in Washington, DC.

item.title: Lightspeed Revenue Tops $1 Billion, Fails to Sway Investors
item.description: Lightspeed Commerce Inc. was the worst performer on the S&P/TSX Composite Index Thursday after the point-of-sale operator reported a $556 million impairment charge amid economic uncertainty for small retailers.
item.dc:creator: Mathieu Dion

media:content.media:description: Dax Dasilva, founder and chairman of Lightspeed Commerce Inc., speaks during the COP15 UN Biodiversity Conference in Montreal, Quebec, Canada, on Monday, Dec. 12, 2022. The goal of COP15, the most important gathering on biodiversity in a decade, is to create a Paris Agreement-style roadmap to protect enough of the world's key ecosystems and slow climate change.

item.title: Crypto DeFi Project Cetus Protocol Suffers Security Breach
item.description: Cetus Protocol, a decentralized crypto exchange and key liquidity provider on the Sui blockchain, said it lost approximately $223 million in a security breach.
item.dc:creator: Sidhartha Shukla

item.title: Mortgage Rates in US Rise for Second Week, Climbing to 6.86%
item.description: Mortgage rates in the US increased for the second week in a row.
item.dc:creator: Prashant Gopal

item.title: Ryan Reynolds' Ad Firm Raises $187 Million in IPO
item.description: Advertising company MNTN and its shareholders raised $187 million in an initial public offering priced at the top of a marketed range. Shares are to begin trading on the New York Stock Exchange Thursday. The Austin-based company — that counts Hollywood star Ryan Reynolds as its chief creative officer — suspended their listing plans after President Donald Trump's tariff announcement on April 2. MNTN CEO Mark Douglas joined Bloomberg Open Interest live from the New York Stock Exchange. (Source: Bloomberg)

item.title: Porsche Is Taking Bids for €750 Million Schuldschein Debt Sale
item.description: Porsche Automobil Holding SE has begun the sale of a Schuldschein transaction of at least €750 million, the largest-ever marketed deal in this niche German debt market.
item.dc:creator: Ronan Martin

media:content.media:description: Porsche headquarters in Stuttgart, Germany.

item.title: Lumen CEO Talks $5.75 Billion Deal With AT&T
item.description: AT&T is buying the consumer fiber business of Lumen Technologies for $5.75 billion. Kate Johnson, the CEO of Lumen Technologies, joined Bloomberg Open Interest to talk about the deal (Source: Bloomberg)

item.title: Rubio Says Venezuela Oil License to End, in Setback for Chevron
item.description: US Secretary of State Marco Rubio said in a post on X that a Venezuela oil-export license will expire next Tuesday, defying earlier expectations that it would be extended.
item.dc:creator: Yongchang Chin, Crayton Harrison

media:content.media:description: A worker passes signage at the Chevron Corp. offices in Caracas, Venezuela, on Thursday, Dec. 1, 2022. The Biden administration granted Chevron a license to resume oil production in Venezuela after US sanctions halted all drilling activities almost three years ago. Photographer: Matias Delacroix/Bloomberg

item.title: TD Plans to Cut About 2% of Workforce Amid Restructuring
item.description: Toronto-Dominion Bank rose after reporting earnings that topped estimates and unveiling a restructuring plan to curb costs that included workforce reductions.
item.dc:creator: Christine Dobby

media:content.media:description: The Toronto-Dominion (TD) bank headquarters in the financial district of Toronto, Ontario, Canada, on Thursday, April 24, 2025. As President Donald Trump's trade war continues, Canadian equities are poised to outperform their US counterparts, portfolio managers argue.

item.title: Carney Looks to AI for Savings as Canada’s Budget Pressures Mount
item.description: Prime Minister Mark Carney said Canada will begin to use artificial intelligence “at scale” to make the government more productive, as his administration looks for ways to squeeze out cost savings in a time of economic pressure.
item.dc:creator: Mathieu Dion, Derek Decloet

media:content.media:description: Mark Carney, Canada's prime minister, left, shakes hands with Francois-Philippe Champagne, Canada's finance minister, after a swearing-in ceremony at Rideau Hall in Ottawa, Ontario, Canada, on Tuesday, May 13, 2025. Carney's new cabinet includes a mix of familiar names and political rookies to carry out his ambitious economic agenda.

item.title: Senate Votes to End California Gas-Car Ban, Sends Bill to Trump
item.description: The US Senate voted to block a California program banning gasoline-powered cars and other vehicles by 2035, sending the measure to President Donald Trump’s desk for his signature.
item.dc:creator: Ari Natter

media:content.media:description: Traffic moves along Interstate 80 in Emeryville, California.

item.title: Dollar Could Drop Another 10%, Says Morgan Stanley's Wilson
item.description: Morgan Stanley CIO and Chief US Equity Strategist Mike Wilson says the US dollar could drop another 10% this year. Morgan Stanely's mid-year outlook says a weaker dollar could drive up US equities. He speaks on "Bloomberg Open Interest." (Source: Bloomberg)

item.title: Rare Private Credit Auction Seeks Bidders in Market Trading Test
item.description: Stifel Financial Corp. is seeking buyers for about $250 million of direct loans held by a client, turning to a practice common in the broadly-syndicated market but rarely seen in private credit to sell the debt.
item.dc:creator: Carmen Arroyo

item.title: Private Credit Eyes Gap in US Infrastructure as Federal Funding Dips
item.description: Private credit firms are seeing an opportunity to finance everything from public transit systems to local utilities as the federal government and banks pull back on funding.
item.dc:creator: Aashna Shah, Ellen Schneider

media:content.media:description: Workers pave a state highway in Streator, Illinois.

item.title: TP ICAP Hit by Multimillion-Euro Ruling Over Role in Dividend Tax Scandal
item.description: TP ICAP Group Plc was hit by a German court ruling ordering it to pick up a potentially multimillion-euro tax bill because the broker allowed its managers to commit crimes with Cum-Ex trading.
item.dc:creator: Karin Matussek

media:content.media:description: Pedestrians walk past the TP ICAP Plc and NEX Group Plc offices on Broadgate Circle in London, U.K., on Thursday, Jan. 5, 2017. Tullett Prebon Plc completed the $1.6 billion purchase of the voice-broker business of its former rival ICAP Plc, creating a new business branded as TP ICAP Plc. ICAP, which sold its name to Tullett as part of the deal, became NEX Group Plc. Photographer: Simon Dawson/Bloomberg

item.title: Morgan's Wilson Says 5% Dip In US Stocks Is Possible
item.description: Morgan Stanley CIO and Chief US Equity Strategist Mike Wilson says a 5% dip or correction is possible after Moody's downgraded the US credit rating. Wilson says he'd be surprised if the S&P 500 drops below 5,500. He speaks about his outlook on "Bloomberg Open Interest." (Source: Bloomberg)

item.title: Buyout Firm EQT Strikes Deal for Water Treatment Provider Seven Seas

item.dc:creator: Ryan Gould

item.description: The European Central Bank must remain vigilant, despite almost having returned inflation to 2%, Governing Council member Joachim Nagel said.

item.title: Telecom Argentina Sells Debt Amid Telefonica Takeover Scrutiny
item.description: Telecom Argentina SA is tapping international debt markets following its acquisition of Telefonica SA’s local unit, a transaction that has stoked fierce opposition from President Javier Milei’s government.
item.dc:creator: Kevin Simauchi

item.title: Yields Likely To Go Higher: Marie-Anne Allier
item.description: Carmignac Fund Manager of Fixed Income Marie-Anne Allier gives her outlook on yield. She speaks with Guy Johnson, Kriti Gupta and Anna Edwards on “The Opening Trade.” (Source: Bloomberg)

item.title: Oil Extends Decline as OPEC+ Considers Another Output Surge
item.description: Oil declined for a third day as US stockpiles gained and OPEC+ members discussed another super-sized production increase for July, just as demand faces headwinds from the US-led trade war.
item.dc:creator: Grant Smith, Christopher Charleston

media:content.media:description: The Deer Park Complex oil refinery and petrochemical plant, owned by Petroleos Mexicanos (PEMEX), in Houston, Texas, US, on Saturday, March 8, 2025. Some 40% of the crude oil processed at US refineries is imported, and Canada and Mexico, the No. 1 and No. 2 foreign suppliers of oil to the US, respectively, together deliver more than two-thirds of that oil. Photographer: Mark Felix/Bloomberg

item.title: Zambia’s Corn Crop More Than Doubles, Bringing Price Relief
item.description: Zambia’s corn harvest will more than double from a 16-year-low last year to a record high, the government said, which could help quell rampant consumer price growth and increase the chance of rate cuts.
item.dc:creator: Taonga Mitimingi

media:content.media:description: A corn seller in Lusaka, Zambia. Photographer: JEAN-CLAUDE COUTAUSSE

item.description: GTCR is already on track to return a record $5 billion-plus to investors for a calendar year, people familiar with the matter said, at a time when peers are under pressure from clients who want their money back.

item.title: Bitcoin Rally Pushes Biggest Token Further Into Record Territory
item.description: Bitcoin surpassed $111,000 for the first time, with traders increasingly bullish on the prospects of the original cryptocurrency amid mounting institutional demand and support from Donald Trump’s administration.
item.dc:creator: Suvashree Ghosh, Sidhartha Shukla

media:content.media:description: A Bitcoin logo inside a cryptocurrency exchange in Barcelona, Spain, on Wednesday, March 9, 2022. Bitcoin dropped back below $40,000, erasing almost all the gains sparked by optimism about U.S. President Joe Biden’s executive order to put more focus on the crypto sector.
